questions.question_text: Which of the following BEST describes a VLAN hopping attack?

discussion.content: VLAN Hopping is an attack where the attacker is able to send traffic from one VLAN into another. There are two different methods to accomplish this: Double tags and switch spoofing

choices.C: An attacker gains unauthorized access to a network by using double-tagged packets.
choices.B: An attacker gains unauthorized access to a network by placing a rogue AP on the network.
choices.A: An attacker gains unauthorized access to a network by overflowing the CAM table.
choices.D: An attacker gains unauthorized access to a network by scanning and mapping it.

questions.question_text: A vendor has installed new wireless access points in an office. After completing the installation, users in one area of the office report they cannot connect to the wireless network. A network technician confirms the users in that area cannot see the wireless SSID. Which of the following MOST likely explains the issue?

choices.C: A directional antenna was installed incorrectly.
choices.A: The AP power levels are too low.
choices.B: The wireless network is over capacity.

discussion.content: "Installed new wireless" can still mean the technician didn't set the initial power levels correctly! Not enough information to accurately answer this one.
Why not include the antenna in the damn question so we can determine if the idiot placed it wrong or not
the keyword here is "installed new wireless"
The solid amber lights depicts a disabled portâ€¦a blinking amber light depicts a problem like duplex mismatch or errors.

comments.content: I think the Q says no configuration changes were made.. Therefore the answer given is correct.

questions.question_text: A switch at a remote site suddenly appears to be inaccessible. No configuration changes were made. An engineer confirms with the office attendant that the switch is powered on, and there are LEDs showing green and amber colors. However, the SFP for the fiber connection from the switch to the router shows no lighted LED. After replacing the cable and SFP with new ones, the LED still does not light up, and no connection is made. Which of the following is the MOST likely issue?

A wireless administrator has configured a secure wireless network that can only be associated to specific domain accounts. This was done to help mitigate any ricks associated with the wireless signal propagating outside of the facility. Which of the following has no administrator implemented?

discussion.content: It'd be nice to have questions with proper grammar.

NAC is the answer here, since the wireless signal isn't contained to the interior of the building, it isn't geofencing, and since the question made sure to state the network access is tied to domain accounts, NAC would be the only plausible option here.

Remember: NAC is Network Access Control, or Network Administrator Control, and is primarily used in Enterprise networks.

Being as tho he configured it to specific domain accounts that's your NAC rite there. He did this to mitigate OUTSIDE risks, there's your geofencing. It's asking what did an administrator NOT do. C is correct

Selected Answer: A
The answer is NAC Network Access Control. Because they are asking about a Domain meaning an Enterprise level.

Network access control (NAC) is a method to restrict access to the network based
on identity or posture . This was created by Cisco
to enforce privileges and make decisions on a client device based on information
gathered from it (such as the vendor and version of the antivirus software
running). If the wanted information is not found (such as that the antivirus
definitions are a year old), the client can be placed in a quarantine network area
to keep it from infecting the rest of the network. It can also be placed in a guest
network and/or allowed to run nonpersistent (versus persistent) agents.

comments.content: this is a firewall rule bro

discussion.content: Why is it not implicit deny?
"Which of the following has NO administrator implemented?" That is the question!??? I believe the correct answer is the given answer of C.
WPA2. You want to mitigate your risk of the signal moving outside the facility by securing the means to access it.
WPA2-Enterprise. I was thinking NAC at first too, but I think WPA2-Enterprise makes more sense.
Has to be A. NAC surely?

questions.question_text:
A network administrator is setting up several IoT devices on a new VLAN and wants to accomplish the following:
1. Reduce manual configuration on each system.
2. Assign a specific IP address to each system.
3. Allow devices to move to different switchports on the same VLAN.
Which of the following should the network administrator do to accomplish these requirements?

comments.content: DHCP exclusions is when you have a specific set of IP addresses that will not be handed out by the DHCP, whereas DHCP reservations are a specific set of chosen IP addresses which are handed out by the DHCP. Meaning, you'd choose exactly what IP addresses you want in your IoT configuration.
Adding onto this, with DHCP Reservation you map an IP address to a MAC address

choices.C: Implement private VLANs for each device.
choices.A: Set up a reservation for each device.
choices.B: Configure a static IP on each device.
choices.D: Use DHCP exclusions to address each device.
